data.title: First Man: Moon-Landing Drama Spurs Very Dumb American-Flag Controversy
data.meta_description: Right-wing Twitter, which has not seen First Man, is freaking out about Damien Chazelle’s decision to omit the American flag from his Neil Armstrong drama. The problem? The flag is actually in the movie.
data.text:
Who knew that people have strong feelings about the American flag?

The Neil Armstrong drama First Man, which debuted at the Venice Film Festival this week (but won’t be released wide until mid-October), has already found itself at the center of a roiling culture-war battle, thanks to its alleged omission of an iconic image: that of the trailblazing astronaut firmly planting the American flag on the moon. The problem? None of the right-wing detractors currently fuming on Twitter have actually seen the film. Oh, and it turns out that the flag was never omitted from the movie in the first place: it can be seen waving on the moon in several shots.

First Man is Damien Chazelle’s follow-up to La La Land, and so far it’s received rave early reviews. The outrage began on Friday, after news outlets began aggregating a Telegraph story stating that the film does not depict Neil Armstrong planting the American flag on the moon. According to V.F.’s correspondent at the Venice Film Festival, who has seen the movie, this is technically true; the film does not have a scene specifically showing the flag being planted. It does, however, show the flag on the moon in multiple background shots.

But thanks to that Telegraph post—cited by publications like Business Insider and the National Review—outrage has spread on the right, fueled by people who seem to believe the flag is absent from the film altogether. People like Florida senator Marco Rubio, who called the supposed decision “total lunacy.”

X content

This content can also be viewed on the site it originates from.

Daily Wire editor in chief Ben Shapiro also clutched his pearls over the movie, writing, “JFK, 1962, on the moon mission: ‘For the eyes of the world now look into space, to the moon and to the planets beyond, and we have vowed that we shall not see it governed by a hostile flag of conquest, but by a banner of freedom and peace.’”

“We literally declared a mission to go to the moon to plant the American flag,” he added. “It wasn't an afterthought. It was the point of the endeavor.”

Another self-appointed film critic who has not actually seen the movie? Weekly Standard editor at large Bill Kristol, who suggested that people complain to Universal Pictures about the missing flag-planting scene—and tagged the studio’s Twitter handle. He called the decision a “foolish and pernicious falsification of history,” adding, “I imagine it’s not too late to add a scene to the movie.”

It bears repeating that the film does not eliminate the image of the American flag on the moon. It simply doesn’t make a big set piece out of the flag’s placement—a decision that seems more closely tied to how the film expresses Armstrong’s emotional arc than it is to the film’s feelings about the U.S., its flag, or patriotism. Though that fact may not be able to stop this growing tempest in an American-flag-branded teapot.
